fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category \mathcal {C} is locally cartesian iff it has pullbacks.

If \mathcal {C} is locally cartesian, then {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} has products for any object A \in \mathcal {C}. But, products in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} are pullbacks over A. Thus, \mathcal {C} has pullbacks.

Conversely, assume that \mathcal {C} has pullbacks. Then since the forgetful functor \Sigma _{A}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to \mathcal {C} creates connected limits for any object A \in \mathcal {C}, the slice {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} has pullbacks. Moreover, \mathsf {id}_{A} is the terminal object in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}. Thus, {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} is cartesian.
A category \mathcal {C} is locally cartesian iff it has pullbacks.

If \mathcal {C} is locally cartesian, then {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} has products for any object A \in \mathcal {C}. But, products in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} are pullbacks over A. Thus, \mathcal {C} has pullbacks.

Conversely, assume that \mathcal {C} has pullbacks. Then since the forgetful functor \Sigma _{A}\colon {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}\to \mathcal {C} creates connected limits for any object A \in \mathcal {C}, the slice {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} has pullbacks. Moreover, \mathsf {id}_{A} is the terminal object in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}}. Thus, {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} is cartesian.

fr:title.text: Slice comparison functor of a locally cartesian category admits a right adjoint

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Slice comparison functor of a locally cartesian category admits a right adjoint

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category \mathcal {C} is locally cartesian iff for all morphisms f of \mathcal {C}, the functor \Sigma _{f} constructed in admits a right adjoint f^{*}. Moreover, f^{*} is (isomorphic to) the pullback functor.
By , locally cartesian categories are precisely those categories with pullbacks.
Suppose that \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*} for any f. We show that the following diagram

is a pullback, where \varepsilon _{g} is the counit of the adjunction. Note that since f \circ f^{*}(g) = \Sigma _{f}(f^{*}(g)) by construction, the component \varepsilon _{g} makes the diagram commute.
Let h'\colon C\to A and h\colon C\to B' be morphisms such that fh' = gh.
Note that h is a morphism h\colon \Sigma _{f}(h')\to g in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. Thus, it corresponds to a unique morphism h^{\dag }\colon h'\to f^{*}(g) under the adjunction.

The transpose of h^{\dag } can be computed as \varepsilon _{g} \circ \Sigma _{f}(h^{\dag }). Since \Sigma _{f} is the identity on morphisms, we have (h^{\dag })^{\dag } = \varepsilon _{g} \circ \Sigma _{f}(h^{\dag }) = \varepsilon _{g} \circ h^{\dag } = h Thus, the top triangle also commutes.
Suppose that \mathcal {C} has pullbacks. Then we can take f^{*} to be the pullback functor. It remains to check that \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*}.
By construction, \varepsilon _{\Sigma _{f}}\eta = \mathsf {id}_{\Sigma _{f}}. Thus, it remains to verify the other triangle equality.

Let g \in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} be an object. We need to show that f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} = \mathsf {id}_{f^{*}(g)}. Note that f^{*}(g)f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} = f^{*}(g) by the construction of f^{*}. Moreover, we also have the following equation.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} \varepsilon _{g}f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} &= \varepsilon _{g}\varepsilon _{f \circ f^{*}(g)}\eta _{f^{*}(g)} && \text {by the construction of } f^{*}\\ &= \varepsilon _{g}\mathsf {id} && \text {by the construction of } \eta \\ &= \varepsilon _{g} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} corresponds to the same cone over f and g as \mathsf {id}_{f^{*}(g)}. Then uniqueness implies that they are equal.

Let T\colon \mathcal {C}^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} be a doctrine with those structures listed in . Additionally, assume that T satisfies Frobenius reciprocity. Then there is a doctrine T^{\flat }\colon \mathsf {Elts}(T)^\mathrm {op}\to \mathsf {Lat} indexed by the syntactic category of T such that T^{\flat } admits comprehension schema.
This proof is adopted from Errol Yuksel's proof. Any error should be attributed to me.

Let us define the action on objects by T^{\flat }(\Gamma .\varphi ) = {{T(\Gamma )}_{/{\varphi }}}. That is, T^{\flat } sends each formula-in-context \Gamma .\varphi to its downward closure ordered by entailment. By assumption, each T(\Gamma ) is cartesian. Thus, each slice {{T(\Gamma )}_{/{\varphi }}} is also cartesian by .
For each morphism f\colon \Gamma .\varphi \to \Delta .\psi , we define T^{\flat }(f) to be the following composite:

where {{T(f)}_{/{\psi }}} sends each \chi \vdash \psi to T(f)(\chi ) \vdash T(f)(\psi ) and \varphi \wedge \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}} is the usual pullback functor along the morphism \varphi \vdash T(f)(\psi ).
This composite admits a left adjoint \exists ^{\flat }_{f} defined as the composite of the top morphisms of the following diagram:
where \Sigma _{\varphi } is the left adjoint in and {{\Sigma _{f}}_{/{\psi }}} is the functor given by the action on morphisms of the left adjoint \Sigma _{f} \dashv T(f).
Let \Gamma |\chi \vdash \varphi . And assume the following pullback square.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \DiagramSquare { width = 4cm, nw = \Gamma '.(T(k)(\varphi ) \wedge T(h)(\psi ')), nw/style = {pullback}, ne = \Delta '.\psi ', sw = \Gamma .\varphi , se = \Delta .\psi , north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We wish to show that T^{\flat }(f)\exists ^{\flat }_{g}(\chi ) \cong \exists ^{\flat }_{h}T^{\flat }(k)(\chi ). The left-hand side computes to \psi ' \wedge T(f){{\Sigma _{g}}_{/{\psi }}}(\chi ), while the right-hand side computes to {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{g}}}(T(k)(\varphi ) \wedge T(h)(\psi ') \wedge T(k)(\chi )). This is isomorphic to \psi ' \wedge {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{\psi '}}}(T(k)(\varphi ) \wedge T(k)(\chi )) by Frobenius reciprocity. T(k), as a right adjoint, commutes with pullbacks. Thus, the right-hand side is isomorphic to \psi ' \wedge {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{\psi '}}}T(k)(\varphi \wedge \chi ). Further, since \chi \vdash \psi , this is isomorphic to \psi ' \wedge {{\Sigma _{h}}_{/{\psi '}}}T(k)(\chi ). Then, \exists ^{\flat }_{f} inherits the Beck-Chevalley condition from \Sigma _{f}.

Since T^{\flat } has all the structures listed in , it admits a naming functor. Let us define {\mathopen {}\{\Gamma .\varphi \colon \mathord {\hspace {1pt}\text {--}\hspace {1pt}}\}\mathclose {}}\colon T^{\flat }(\Gamma .\varphi )\to {{\mathsf {Elts}(T)}_{/{\Gamma .\varphi }}} by

Let \gamma \colon \Delta .\chi \to \Gamma .\varphi and \psi \in T(\Gamma ) such that \psi \vdash \varphi . Then {\mathopen {}[\gamma ]\mathclose {}}_{\Gamma .\varphi } \leq \psi iff \exists _{\gamma }(\chi ) \leq \psi iff \chi \leq T^{\flat }(\gamma )(\psi ) iff \chi \leq T(\gamma )(\psi ). But there is a morphism \gamma \to {\mathopen {}\{\Gamma .\varphi \colon \psi \vdash \varphi \}\mathclose {}} iff \chi \leq T(\gamma )(\psi ). Thus,

fr:title.text: Slice comparison functor of a locally cartesian category admits a right adjoint

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Slice comparison functor of a locally cartesian category admits a right adjoint

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category \mathcal {C} is locally cartesian iff for all morphisms f of \mathcal {C}, the functor \Sigma _{f} constructed in admits a right adjoint f^{*}. Moreover, f^{*} is (isomorphic to) the pullback functor.
By , locally cartesian categories are precisely those categories with pullbacks.
Suppose that \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*} for any f. We show that the following diagram

is a pullback, where \varepsilon _{g} is the counit of the adjunction. Note that since f \circ f^{*}(g) = \Sigma _{f}(f^{*}(g)) by construction, the component \varepsilon _{g} makes the diagram commute.
Let h'\colon C\to A and h\colon C\to B' be morphisms such that fh' = gh.
Note that h is a morphism h\colon \Sigma _{f}(h')\to g in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}}. Thus, it corresponds to a unique morphism h^{\dag }\colon h'\to f^{*}(g) under the adjunction.

The transpose of h^{\dag } can be computed as \varepsilon _{g} \circ \Sigma _{f}(h^{\dag }). Since \Sigma _{f} is the identity on morphisms, we have (h^{\dag })^{\dag } = \varepsilon _{g} \circ \Sigma _{f}(h^{\dag }) = \varepsilon _{g} \circ h^{\dag } = h Thus, the top triangle also commutes.
Suppose that \mathcal {C} has pullbacks. Then we can take f^{*} to be the pullback functor. It remains to check that \Sigma _{f} \dashv f^{*}.
By construction, \varepsilon _{\Sigma _{f}}\eta = \mathsf {id}_{\Sigma _{f}}. Thus, it remains to verify the other triangle equality.

Let g \in {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{B}}} be an object. We need to show that f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} = \mathsf {id}_{f^{*}(g)}. Note that f^{*}(g)f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} = f^{*}(g) by the construction of f^{*}. Moreover, we also have the following equation.
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {align*} \varepsilon _{g}f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} &= \varepsilon _{g}\varepsilon _{f \circ f^{*}(g)}\eta _{f^{*}(g)} && \text {by the construction of } f^{*}\\ &= \varepsilon _{g}\mathsf {id} && \text {by the construction of } \eta \\ &= \varepsilon _{g} \end {align*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Thus, f^{*}(\varepsilon _{g})\eta _{f^{*}(g)} corresponds to the same cone over f and g as \mathsf {id}_{f^{*}(g)}. Then uniqueness implies that they are equal.
A category \mathcal {C} is said to be locally cartesian if for any object A \in \mathcal {C}, the slice {{\mathcal {C}}_{/{A}}} is cartesian.
